fields.title: academic years
fields.content: When referring to the academic year that begins in fall 2016 and ends in spring 2017, use 2016-2017.

fields.title: accent marks
fields.content: Use accent marks for proper nouns such as Bruin Café or Beyoncé. Do not use an accent mark in general uses of words such as cafe, naivete, facade.

fields.title: actor names in reviews
fields.content: for reviews only, after we introduce a character, we put the name of the actor who plays them in parenthesis

fields.title: African American studies, Asian American studies
fields.content: Do not hyphenate if referring to the major.

fields.title: Anaheim
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Arthur Ashe Student Health and Wellness Center
fields.content: Arthur Ashe Student Health and Wellness Center on first reference. On subsequent references and in headlines, Ashe Center or student health and wellness center is acceptable.

fields.title: Associated Students UCLA
fields.content: Associated Students UCLA on first reference. ASUCLA is acceptable on subsequent references.

fields.title: at UCLA
fields.content: If a club or organization name has at UCLA as part of its official name, state it on first reference.

fields.title: Bakersfield
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Baseball, softball
fields.content:
**Positions**

* C - Catcher (2)
* Infielders
+ 1B - First baseman (3)
+ 2B - Second baseman (4)
+ SS - Shortstop (6)
+ 3B - Third baseman (5)
* Outfield
+ LF - Left fielder (7)
+ CF - Center fielder (8)
+ RF - Right fielder (9)
+ DH - Designated hitter
+ DP - Designated player (Softball only)
* P - Pitcher (1)
+ SP - Starting pitcher
+ RP - Relief pitcher
+ Set-up man+ Closer

* Leadoff hitter - the first hitter


In a baseball/softball story, you might see a reference to a 4-6-3 double play (or some other numbers), this means the play went from the second baseman (4) to the shortstop (6) to the first baseman (3)

**Stats**

Batting:

* AB - At-bats (Word), when a hitter goes to bat and gets either a hit or is out. Walks and hits by pitch do not count for at-bats* PA - Plate appearance, when a hitter goes to bat. (At-bats+walks+hits by pitch)* H - Hits (Word), when a hitter reaches base after hitting the ball.
* R - Runs (word)* RBIs - Runs batted in (word), the runs a batter’s hit results in being scored.
* BB - Walks, when a hitter reaches base after four balls* K/SO - Strikeouts, when a hitter is out after three strikes.
* Full count - when a batter in a 3-2 counts (3 balls, 2 strikes* LOB - Runner stranded on base* RISP - Runner in scoring position, when a runner is on second or third base.
* HR - Home run (Word), when a batter hits the ball out of the park* Solo home run - a home run where one person scores* S - Steal.
* HBP - Hit by pitch, when a batter is hit by a pitch and and advances to first base. One of the few terms in baseball which exactly what it sounds like.
* BA/AVG - Batting average (H/AB)

	+ A batting average above .300 is very good+ A batting average between .200 and .300 is some level between passable and good.
	+ A batting average below .200 is bad and probably means hitting baseballs is something you’re bad at.
	
	* OBP - On-base percentage (H+BB+HBP)/(AB+BB+HBP+Sacrifice flys)
* SLG - Slugging percentage (Singles + (Doubles*2) + (Triples*3) + (Home Runs*4) / AB)* OPS: On-base plug slugging (SLG% + OB%)
* .XXX/.YYY/.ZZZ - The triple slash (BA/OBP/SLG)
* Single - advances to first base* Double - advances to second base
* Triple - advances to third base* Sac fly - Sacrifice fly, when a hitter ‘sacrifices himself’ so another runner can advance to another base* Extra-base hits - doubles, triples, and home runs
* Sac bunt














Pitching:

* IP - Innings pitched (use style of 1 1/3 , not 1.1)
* Baseball is divided into nine innings (also referred to as frames) and softball is divided into seven. In each inning, except sometimes the ninth, each team bats and pitches once. Each 1/3 of an inning represents one batter getting out. Three outs ends an inning.
* W-L - Wins-losses record for pitchers. The pitcher who is pitching when the winning run is scored gets the win/loss.
* No decision - When a pitcher pitches, but does not receive a win or loss.
* R - Runs
* ER - Earned runs (not the same as runs, is when a run is scored by a hitter who reached on base not off an error)
* BB - Walks. When a pitcher throws four balls.
* K/SO - Strikeouts. When a pitcher throws three strikes.
* WP - Wild pitch
* BK - Balk
* HBP - Hit by pitch
* IBB - Intentional walk
* BF - Batters faced
* NP - Number of pitches
* H - Hold
* S/SV - Save. A save is a bit complicated, so here is a nice link.
* ERA - Earned run average (ER / IP * 9). The lower, the better.
+ An ERA below 2 is rare, while an ERA above 5 is concerning
* WHIP - Walks plus hits per inning pitched ([BB+H]/IP). The lower, the better.
* Complete game - when a pitcher pitches the entire game. Relatively rare.
* No-hitter - when a pitcher does not allow a hit for an entire game. Rare.
* Perfect game - when a pitcher does not allow a man on base for an entire game. Very rare.


Fielding:

* Outs - there are three outs in each inning.
* Ground out
* Strikeout
* Fly out
* Sac fly


**Common Terminology**

* UCLA plays in the Pac-12, which is baseball only has 11 teams and in softball, 9 teams:
+ UCLA+ USC (no softball team)
+ Utah
+ Arizona
+ Arizona State
+ Washington
+ Washington State (no softball team)
+ Oregon
+ Oregon State
+ Stanford
+ California

* The college baseball postseason consists of the Pac-12 tournament and NCAA tournament, which ends with the College World Series. The college softball postseason consists of the same tournaments, though the final round is called the Women’s College World Series.
* Unlike other sports, the baseball and softball NCAA tournaments are double elimination, meaning a team needs to lose two games to be eliminated, not one.
* In both baseball and softball, seasons are divided into series, sets of three or four games between the same teams. Winning a series means winning a majority of these games. Sweeping a series means winning all of them.


**Rankings**

The Daily Bruin uses the D1Baseball.com rankings. Another commonly referenced ranking is the Rating Percentage Index (RPI) rankings.

fields.title: basketball
fields.content:
**Stats:**

* MIN - Minutes
* In college basketball, games are 40 minutes
* FGA - Field goal attempts (includes 3-point shots)
* FGM - Field goals made
* FG - Field goals, any shot which a free throw
* FG% - Field goal percentage (FGM/FGA)
* 3PT - 3-point shots
* A 3PT% above 40 is very good and a 3PT% below 33 is bad. Shots from the 3-point line are described as “beyond the arc”
* FT - Free throw (the free throw line is sometime referred to as the charity stripe)
* FT% - Free throw percentage
* OREB/ORB - Offensive rebounds
* DREB/DRB - Defensive rebounds
* REB/TOT - Rebounds (offensive rebounds + defensive rebounds)
* PF - Personal fouls (if you get five fouls you foul out, if you get one or two, you’re in foul trouble)
* A/AST - Assists
* TO - Turnovers
* BLK - Blocks
* STL - Steals
* PTS - Points
* 2ndChPts - Second chance points
* PtsPaint - points in the paint
* eFG% - Effective field goal percentage (FGM + (0.5*3PT made) / FGA)
* Triple-double - When a player gets 10+ in three stats other than turnovers or fouls (typically points, rebounds, and assists)
* Double-double - When a player gets 10+ in two stats other than turnovers or fouls
* Five-by-five - When a player gets 5+ in at least five stats other than turnovers or fouls
* Fast break - when a team attempts to move the ball up court and into scoring position as quickly as possible
* The paint - the painted area of the basketball court near the basket
* Free throw line - not hyphenated
* 3s - 3 pointers are written as numerals


**Positions:**

* Guards
* PG/1 - Point guard
* SG/2 - Shooting guards
* Forwards
* SF/3 - Small forwards
* PF/4 - Power forwards
* C/5 - Center
* Wings: Shooting guards and small forwards
* Big man: Centers and occasionally power forwards


**Common terminology:**

* UCLA plays in the Pacific-12 Conference. Teams in the Pac-12 include:
+ California
+ Stanford
+ USC
+ UCLA
+ Arizona (In men’s basketball, Arizona and UCLA are traditionally the two best teams in the Pac-12 and have an intense rivalry.)
+ Arizona State
+ Colorado
+ Utah
+ Washington
+ Washington State
+ Oregon
+ Oregon State


UCLA is considered a mens college basketball blue blood, meaning that historically it is one of the best programs in the country. The other blue bloods typically include Duke, North Carolina, Indiana, Kentucky and Kansas.

There is currently a massive FBI investigation into men’s college basketball.

Each Pac-12 team plays 18 conference games, along with about 12 out-of-conferences games every year.

The postseason of college basketball includes the Pac-12 tournament, which consists of every team in the Pac-12 competing for an automatic bid to the NCAA tournament, which is the final competition. If a team does not win an automatic bid, it can still get an at-large bid. The NCAA tournament is more commonly known as March Madness.

Rankings: The Daily Bruin uses the AP Poll for both mens and womens basketball. Other commonly referenced rankings in DB stories are KenPom.coms rankings and the NCAA NET ratings.

fields.title: Berkeley
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Beverly Hills
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Big Blue Bus
fields.content: Use Santa Monica Big Blue Bus on first reference. Big Blue Bus can be used on second reference.

fields.title: Billy Wilder Theater
fields.content: Billy Wilder Theater on first reference. On subsequent references, theater is acceptable.

fields.title: board of directors, board of trustees
fields.content: Always lowercase.

fields.title: Bombshelter, Court of Sciences Student Center
fields.content: Court of Sciences Student Center somewhere in the body of the story to refer to the building. Bombshelter OK on other references, headlines, and in quotes.

fields.title: Bruin Café
fields.content: Include an accent mark per the "accent marks" entry. Do not abbreviate *BCafe*.

fields.title: Bruin Film Society
fields.content: BFS on second reference.

fields.title: Bruin Plate
fields.content: B Plate on second reference

fields.title: Bruin Walk
fields.content: Use to describe the physical location.

fields.title: Bruinwalk
fields.content: When referring to the professor review website, use "Bruinwalk" For the physical location on campus, see the Bruin Walk entry.

fields.title: Burbank
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Café 1919
fields.content: Include an accent mark per the "accent marks" entry.

fields.title: California cities
fields.content:
The following cities in California stand alone:

* Anaheim
* Bakersfield
* Berkeley
* Beverly Hills
* Burbank
* Culver City
* Davis
* Fresno
* Glendale
* Irvine
* Malibu
* Marina del Rey
* Merced
* Oakland
* Pasadena
* Riverside
* Sacramento
* Santa Barbara
* San Bernardino
* Santa Cruz
* Santa Monica
* West Hollywood


In stories about football, *Pasadena* also stands alone. Per the AP Stylebook, *Los Angeles*, *San Francisco* and *San Diego* already stand alone.

fields.title: campus buildings
fields.content:
For buildings and locations that do not appear here, refer to UCLA’s website and include just the last name of the individual whom the building or location is named after.

For professional schools and relevant buildings, on first reference, use the formal name in headline case: Anderson School of Management. On subsequent references, use School of Management or management school.

Similarly, use Terasaki Life Sciences Building on first reference. On second and subsequent reference, life sciences building is acceptable.For the names of centers, on second reference capitalize Center only if it follows a proper noun:

* Gonda Center* Ashe Center* alumni center




The exception is for Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center, which should never be abbreviated. On second and subsequent references, use the medical center or the hospital.

fields.title: Campus Queries
fields.content:
Set the Q&A part off from the italicized blurb at the beginning and bold the Q and A. In Campus Queries, you should get a flag above the headline, the headline should be a question, and the question and answers should be justified.

*Campus Queries is a series in which Daily Bruin readers and staff present science-related questions for UCLA professors and experts to answer.*

enter here

**Q:** What are deepfakes?

**A:** Deepfake videos transform a recording of someone into artificial scenarios that never actually occurred using machine learning algorithms.

fields.title: campus room numbers
fields.content: Use the abbreviated form for rooms in campus buildings: *Math Sciences 4210*, not *Math Sciences Building, Room 4210.*

fields.title: catch-and-run
fields.content: hyphenate as a noun

fields.title: CCLE
fields.content: Short for Common Collaborative Learning Environment. Use CCLE on all references.

fields.title: championship, tournament
fields.content: lowercase the c in championship and do not use championships unless referring to multiple championships

fields.title: Charles E. Young Research Library
fields.content: Charles E. Young Research Library on first reference. For subsequent references, Young Research Library is acceptable.

fields.title: Chicana/o and Central American studies
fields.content: refer to the major in this way rather than the way the website does

fields.title: city of Los Angeles
fields.content: with lowercase city

fields.title: colons
fields.content: Names of events or organizations with a colon should be given in full on first reference. On subsequent references, you can drop the portion after the colon. Ex: All of Us: A Campaign to Rethink Mental Health.

fields.title: communication
fields.content: The major is communication, not communication studies; e.g. Mackenzie Possee, a third-year communication student.

fields.title: Community Programs Office
fields.content: CPO is acceptable on second reference.

fields.title: comprises
fields.content: should be *comprises* or *composed of* not *comprised of*.

fields.title: CONCACAF
fields.content: Say CONCACAF, but at some point in the story state that it is the professional soccer governing body in North and Central America and the Caribbean.

fields.title: contributing reports
fields.content:
Contributing reports should be at the end of the story online and be stylized in italics.

*Contributing reports from Joe Bruin, Daily Bruin senior staff.*

In print, contributing reports should be stylized as *Contributing reports from Tommy Trojan, Daily Bruin senior staff. Email Bruin at jbruin@dailybruin.com or tweet@jbruinDB.*

fields.title: council member, councilmember
fields.content: When referring to a general member of a council, the two-word construction works. For formal titles, use the gender-neutral one-word construction as in "Councilmember Paul Koretz" to follow the stated formal titles which can be found on all of the websites of the council members. Treat "assembly member" and "Assemblymember" similarly.

fields.title: course titles
fields.content: The subject and course number should be followed by a colon and the course name in quotes: Political Science 10: "Introduction to Political Theory." Use numerals for the course number.; on second reference use the subject and the course number, ex: Political Science 10

fields.title: Covel Commons Residential Restaurant
fields.content: Covel dining hall or just Covel second reference if clear you’re referring to dining hall

fields.title: crimewatch
fields.content: in standalone crimewatch graphic, keep the title as one word

fields.title: cross country
fields.content: Note that there is no hyphen. This is an exception to AP Stylebook but in accordance with the governing bodies of the sport.

fields.title: CSU schools
fields.content: Spell out California State University and with the specific schools add the schools after on first reference; ex: California State University, Chico on first reference

fields.title: Culver City
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Daily Bruin
fields.content: Do not use quotations or italics. The Bruin is acceptable on second reference. e.g. We work many hours at The Bruin.

fields.title: Daily Bruin Editorial Board
fields.content: Use editorial board when standing alone: *The editorial board called upon the union to not prolong contract negotiations.*

fields.content:
**Upper**

* Editor in chief
* Managing editor
* Digital Managing editor


**Arts**

* Arts editor
* Theater | film | television
* Music | fine arts
*  Lifestyle


**Blogging**

* Blogging editor
* assistant Blogging editor

**Design**

**Enterprise**

* Enterprise production editor
* Enterprise content editor


**Graphics**

**Illustrations**

**News**

* News editor
* Campus politics editor
* Science and health editor
* National news and higher education editor
* City and crime editor
* Features and student life


**Online**

fields.title: David Geffen School of Medicine
fields.content: David Geffen School of Medicine on first reference. On subsequent references, School of Medicine is acceptable.

fields.title: Davies Children’s Health Center
fields.content: Davies Children’s Health Center on first reference. For subsequent references, either Davies Center or children’s health center is acceptable.

fields.title: Davis
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: De Neve Auditorium
fields.content: this is a room not a building

fields.title: De Neve residence halls
fields.content:
On first reference, refer to the residences in De Neve Plaza as * De Neve Acacia
* De Neve Birch
* De Neve Cedar
* De Neve Dogwood
* De Neve Evergreen
* De Neve Fir
* De Neve Gardenia
* De Neve Holly


Refer to just the tree name on second reference (e.g. Acacia, Birch, etc.).

fields.title: De Neve Residential Restaurant
fields.content: De Neve dining hall or just De Neve second reference clear you’re referring to dining hall

fields.title: dining hall
fields.content: Do not capitalize, even when referring to a particular dining hall: De Neve dining hall, Covel dining hall.

fields.title: double majors
fields.content: List in alphabetical order

fields.title: draft
fields.content: for all sports drafts, capitalize the D. ex: NBA draft

fields.title: dual match
fields.content: When there are only two teams competing against each other. Ex: For gymnastics, if it was a meet with four different teams competing it would not be a dual. But if it was just UCLA directly in competition with ONLY one other team (like Stanford) then it would be called a dual.

fields.title: due to, because of
fields.content:
1. Use ‘due to’ only to modify nouns.

2. Usage of ‘due to’ is correct, if the sentence makes sense when ‘due to’ is replaced with ‘caused by’ or ‘as a result of.’

3. Use ‘because of’ to modify verbs.

4. ‘Due to’ and ‘because of’ are not interchangeable.

fields.title: emailed statement
fields.content: not email statement

fields.title: FAFSA
fields.content: use FAFSA on all references

fields.title: Feast at Rieber
fields.content: just FEAST on second reference is fine

fields.title: Fernald Child Development Center
fields.content: Fernald Child Development Center on first reference. For subsequent references, either child development center or Fernald Center is acceptable.

fields.title: Fielding School of Public Health
fields.content: Fielding School of Public Health on first reference, on subsequent references School of Public Health is OK.

fields.title: First Team, Second Team
fields.content: caps after All-Pac-12 (or whatever conference it may be) or All-American

fields.title: flyer
fields.content: Can be used as a noun or a verb to refer to either a pamphlet to be handed out or the act of handing out a pamphlet.

fields.title: football
fields.content:
This refers to American football.

**Common terminology:**

UCLA plays in the Pacific-12 Conference. The Pac-12 is one of the five power conferences. The other power conferences include the ACC, SEC, Big 12 and Big Ten.

* Pac-12 North
* Oregon Ducks
* Oregon State Beavers
* Washington Huskies
* Washington State Cougars
* Stanford Cardinal
* California Golden Bears
* Pac-12 South
* UCLA Bruins
* USC Trojans
* Arizona Wildcats
* Arizona State Sun Devils
* Utah Utes
* Colorado Buffaloes


The winners of the two divisions play each other in the Pac-12 championship game.

The postseason tournament for Division I FBS college football is the College Football Playoff, which is a four-team single-elimination tournament. It has been decades since UCLA has been good enough to reach this.

If a team does not make the playoff, it plays in a bowl game, a one-off exhibition game. The most prestigious bowl games are the New Year’s Six Bowl Games (Rose, Orange, Cotton, Fiesta, Sugar, Peach). There are a couple dozen other, less prestigious bowl games. UCLA has been yet to play in one of the prestigious games in the 21st century.

Rankings: The Daily Bruin uses the AP poll for the first half of the season, until the College Football Playoff starts to release rankings around mid-October.

**Passing Stats:**

* Comp./C - Completions
* Att. - Attempts
* Yds. - Passing yards
* TD - Touchdowns
* INT - Interceptions
* YPA/AVG - Yards per attempt
* Rating - Passer rating (NOT THE SAME AS QBR)


**Rushing Stats:**

* Car/Att. - Carries/Attempts
* Yds. - Rushing Yards
* Net in UCLABruins.com (Gain-Loss)
* YPC/Avg. - Yards per carry


**Receiving Stats:**

* Rec. - Receptions
* Yds. - Receiving Yards
* Avg. - Yards per reception


**Defensive Stats:**

* Solo - Solo tackles
* Ast - Assisted tackles
* Tot - Total tackles (Solo+Assisted)
* TFL - Tackles for loss
* Sack - Sack
* FF - Forced fumbles
* PD - Passes defended
* QB HUR - Quarterback hurries


**Special Teams Stats:**

* FG - Field goals
* PAT/XP - Extra points
* TB - Touchbacks
* Yds. - Punting yards
* In. 20 - Punts inside the 20-yard line


**Positions:**

* Offense
+ QB - Quarterback
+ HB/RB - Halfback/Running Back
+ FB - Fullback
+ WR - Wide Receiver
* Types of receivers include outside and slot receivers:
+ TE - Tight End
+ OL - Offensive Line
+ OT/LT/RT - Offensive/left/right tackle
+ OG/LG/RG - Offensive/left/right guard
+ C - Center
* Defense
+ DL - Defensive Line
+ DE/LE/DE - Defensive/left/right end
+ DT/NT - Defensive/nose tackle
+ LB - Linebacker
+ MLB/Mike - Middle linebacker
+ OLB/Will/Sam - Outside linebackers
+ DB - Defensive backs/Secondary
+ CB - Cornerbacks
* Types of cornerbacks include outside, nickel and dime corners:
+ S - Safety
+ FS/SS - Free/strong safety
* Special Teams
+ K - Kickers
+ P - Punters
+ RS - Return specialists
+ KR - Kick returner
+ PR - Punt returner

fields.title: Fowler Museum
fields.content: Although its website lists the "at UCLA" in its name, the story should provide enough context. "At UCLA" is unnecessary. On second ref, "Fowler" is acceptable.

fields.title: Fresno
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: gameday
fields.content: one word

fields.title: general education
fields.content: GE can be used on second reference

fields.title: Glendale
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: golf
fields.content:
* Birdie: 1-under par
* Eagle: 2-under par
* Bogey: 1-over par
* Double bogey: 2-over par


On stat sheets:

* red is a birdie
* yellow is an eagle
* green is a bogey
* blue is a double bogey

fields.title: Gonda Neuroscience and Genetics Research Center
fields.content: Gonda Neuroscience and Genetics Research Center on first reference. For subsequent references, either neuroscience and genetics research center or Gonda Center is acceptable.

fields.title: Grace on Campus
fields.content: GOC on second reference

fields.title: grad, undergrad
fields.content: Do not use the shortened forms of graduate and undergraduate in body text. *Grad* and *undergrad* are acceptable in headlines as adjectives only when space is tight.

fields.title: grades
fields.content: stylize as A+, B- not A-plus or B-minus

fields.title: Graduate School of Education and Information Studies
graduate student
fields.content:
Do not include the year of study, and do not distinguish between students in master\'s programs and Ph.D. programs. This is for simplification purposes, as there are differences between a master\'s/Ph.D. degree student and master\'s/Ph.D. degree candidate. Correct: *She is a graduate student in public health.*

If someone is a graduate, call them an alum; if someone is a graduate student say “major graduate student” or “graduate student in major”

fields.title: GSA
fields.content: Graduate Students Association. Spell out on first reference.

fields.title: gymnastics scores
fields.content:
Round scores to third decimal point, except for perfect 10s, which should be written as *10*

Leave off the zeros at the end of scores for personal scores, as in "Ross scored a 9.95." However, extend to the full accuracy for event scores and team scores, as in "UCLA scored a 49.500 on bars, and UCLA finished the meet with a 195.700."

fields.title: hackathaon
fields.content: Follow the standard of Merriam-Websters entries for other "-athons," which do not include the hyphen.

fields.title: Hawaii
fields.content: No apostrophe when referring to the state. Use Hawai’i in sports stories about the university.

fields.title: headlines
fields.content:
* Numbers in headlines are always figures unless at the beginning of the headline or are spelled out as part of a proper noun.
* Anything that would be in double quotes in a story is in single quotes in a headline.
* Headlines don’t use periods for acronyms – so no U.S.
* Million is abbreviated to M in headlines – $1M, the same goes for thousands (10,000 -> 10K)
* Limit the amount of commas used to one.
* No using the same word twice in one headline.
* Try to remove all articles – the, a
* Remember to add column names in front of headlines as appropriate such as “Editorial:” “Album review:” “The Quad:” “Q&A:”
* Remember that when we do reviews, the r is always lowercase in headlines.
* Also, when we do reviews, include the name of what we are reviewing in the headline.
* Galleries should always have “Gallery:” in front of the headline.
* The character limits are 55-82.

fields.title: homeless, homelessness
fields.content: say a person who is experiencing homelessness or a person who is homeless, NOT a homeless person

fields.title: HOOLIGAN Theatre Company
fields.content: The all-caps style is per request of club leaders.

fields.title: Hugh and Hazel Darling Law Library
iClicker
fields.content: Use clicker on second reference

fields.title: individual medley
fields.content: individual medley on first reference, IM on second

fields.title: Indus at UCLA
fields.content: use Indus on second reference

fields.title: International Fraternity Council
fields.content: use IFC on second reference. Do not use IFC in headlines.

fields.title: Irvine
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: J.D. Morgan Center
fields.content: J.D. Morgan Center on first reference. For subsequent references, intercollegiate athletic center is acceptable.

fields.title: James West Alumni Center
fields.content: James West Alumni Center on first reference. For subsequent references, either alumni center or James West Center is acceptable.

fields.title: Japanese Animation Club
fields.content: JAC on second reference

fields.title: Kerckhoff Charles E. Young Grand Salon
fields.content: Kerckhoff Grand Salon on second ref

fields.title: Kerckhoff Coffeehouse
fields.content: Based on the sign outside the cafe and the Kerckhoff worker, coffeehouse is one word.

fields.title: LA cities
fields.content:
Cities can be standalone because of association with UCLA, how well-known they are or clarity from context.

 Some places with an obvious UCLA connection include Santa Monica, Marina del Rey, Pasadena and Westwood. Obvious places include Hollywood, West Hollywood, Bel Air and Beverly Hills. In general though, there should be some context that clarifies that these a city, neighborhood or area in Los Angeles or Southern California.

fields.title: language majors
fields.content: If a student majors in a foreign language refer to them as a language and culture student. E.g. Josie Bruin, a fourth-year political science and Korean language and culture student.

fields.title: LAPD
fields.content: use on all references for the Los Angeles Police Department

fields.title: last
fields.content: The word *last* is not necessary to convey the notion of most recent when the name of a month or day is used:Preferred: *It happened Wednesday. It happened in April.* Correct, but redundant: *It happened last Wednesday.*But: *It happened last week. It happened last month.*

fields.title: Latino
fields.content: use instead of Hispanic or Latinx

fields.title: LGBTQ+
fields.content: Daily Bruin style retains the plus

fields.title: Los Angeles County Museum of Art, LACMA
fields.content: LACMA on second reference

fields.title: Los Angeles International Airport, LAX
fields.content: LAX is acceptable on all references

fields.title: Los Angeles Metropolitan Transportation Authority
fields.content: Los Angeles Metro on first reference if LA is not already mentioned in story, otherwise LA Metro or just Metro

fields.title: Los Angeles Tennis Center
fields.content: Los Angeles Tennis Center on first reference. For subsequent references, tennis center is acceptable.

fields.title: Los Angeles, LA
fields.content: Los Angeles on first refernece, LA on second references. Los Angeles OK on second reference but it should be consistently done throughout story.

fields.title: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library
fields.content: Louise M. Darling Biomedical Library on first reference, on second ref, Biomedical Library is fine.

fields.title: Love Trumps Hate rally
fields.content: Use "Love Trumps Hate" rally based on other media organizations and the fact that "Love Trumps Hate" is a slogan and an idea around which the rally or event is organized.

fields.title: lowercase names
fields.content: for peoples names that use lowercases, retain the lowercase on all references, in respect to peoples identities, but try your best to rephrase the sentence as best as possible. for proper nouns that are names or organizations or events, we can uppercase it at the beginning of a sentence.

fields.title: Malibu
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Marina del Rey
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: mathematics/economics student
fields.content: use the slash

fields.title: MEChA
fields.content: Acronym for Movimiento Estudiantil Chicano de Aztlan, a Latino student group on campus. MEChA is acceptable in all references.

fields.title: Merced
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Metro lines
fields.content: Treat them like streets. Capitalize the "line" when it is referring to a single line. If referring to multiple, then lowercase the "lines." Ex: Expo and Purple lines. Expo Line

fields.title: MFA
fields.content: For grad students, say "graduate student in fine arts." If used in the name of an event such as "MFA Exhibition," include an explanation such as "an event where graduate students in fine arts showcase their work."

fields.title: microbiology, immunology and molecular genetics, MIMG
fields.content: no Oxford comma. MIMG is acceptable on second reference.

fields.title: Model United Nations at UCLA
fields.content: use MUN at UCLA on second reference

fields.title: molecular, cell, and developmental biology, MCDB
fields.content: use Oxford comma, MCDB is acceptable on second reference

fields.title: Mountain Pacific Sports Federation, MPSF
fields.content: Use Mountain Pacific Sports Federation on first reference except when it’s included as part of a record. Use MPSF on subsequent references.

fields.title: movie or book reviews
fields.content: Refer to characters by their first names unless they are referred to by last names in the work of art; make sure that actors are put in parentheses after character names

fields.title: Franklin D. Murphy Sculpture Garden
fields.content: Sculpture Garden is fine on second ref

fields.title: Muslim Student Association, MSA
fields.content: use MSA on second reference

fields.title: names in headlines
fields.content: Last names are OK for the most popular/well-known. For example, Mora and Rosen. Names in headlines with positions are OK if they play a big part in the game. Definitely put the name in a feature headline and words to convey the sport.

fields.title: National Panhellenic Conference
fields.content: national sorority governing body

fields.title: NCAA Division I Football Bowl Subdivision, FBS
fields.content: use FBS on all references

fields.title: NCAA West Regional, cross country
fields.content: caps the W and the R

fields.title: New Student Orientation
fields.content: lower freshman orientation and transfer student orientation

fields.title: newspapers
fields.content:
* Los Angeles Times
* The New York Times
* Washington Post
* The Wall Street Journal
* The Daily Californian

fields.title: North Westwood Neighborhood Council, NWWNC
fields.content: NWWNC is acceptable on second reference

fields.title: Oakland
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: organization names
fields.content: Use the capitalization that the organization prefers. For example, ScatterTones is used in the Facebook, YouTube and Wikipedia websites.

fields.title: Pasadena
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: personal records, PR
fields.content: Write out as set a personal record on the first reference. On subsequent references, PR or PRed may be used.

fields.title: photo captions
fields.content: if there are more than four people in a photo and all of them are named in the caption, refer to them as "First Last, First Last, First Last, First Last (left to right)"

fields.title: pre-major
fields.content: Use this term when a student needs to apply to the major before they are accepted or when a student identifies themselves as such. For example, pre-international development studies.

fields.title: pre-professional students
fields.content: hyphenate students in pre-professional programs e.g. pre-medical student, pre-law student

fields.title: preferred names
fields.content: Use a persons preferred name (i.e. what they introduce themselves as to a reporter). For example, Samuel Hoff may be shortened to Sam Hoff.

fields.title: PRIME
fields.content: not prime

fields.title: professional schools
fields.content: use "School of Medicine," "School of Law," etc. on second reference

fields.title: professional sports teams
fields.content: use city name and team name on first reference. ex: the Los Angeles Lakers, not just the Lakers. On subsequent refs, just Lakers is fine

fields.title: public comments
fields.content: the US Senators are identified as e.g. “Kamala Harris, U.S. Senator from California” (Its Sen. Kamala Harris in text, but after the quote its senator)

fields.title: public relations, PR
fields.content: use PR on all references

fields.title: Q&A format (in print)
fields.content:
In Q&As, the questions should be justified and the answers should be left aligned. There should be an extra enter in between every Q&A block. On first reference, put the person who is being interviewed and Daily Bruin in bold and on all other references bold the initials.

**Daily Bruin:** You’ve said a lot of your character in “Always Be My Maybe” came from personal experience, but was there anything you were hesitant to include? Or did you want to be fairly candid?

**Randall Park:** I was pretty open because it certainly helped that I was writing it with two friends of mine, Ali Wong and Michael Golamco, who I’ve known for a very long time. It helped create this comfort level when we were writing where we would just be open about our stories that we wanted to incorporate into the script. And we were familiar with each other’s stories because we have known each other for so long that whenever something felt natural to put it in the script it was something that we all knew about. Not always, but a lot of the times we already were privy to those stories.

enter here

**DB:** While at UCLA, you co-founded Lapu, the Coyote that Cares Theatre Company – how do you think that has impacted your career?

**RP:** That was pivotal in my life, that theater company. It was a huge reason why, eventually, I decided to pursue acting professionally – because I fell in love with it at UCLA. I had no experience acting before UCLA. It was through that theater company that I discovered the power of acting and writing, because at LCC we would perform our own original material.

fields.title: Ralphs
fields.content: no apostrophe

fields.title: records
fields.content: Write records with parallelism: "UCLA men’s soccer (4-4-1, 0-2 Pac-12) San Diego State (3-4-0, 0-2)" NOT "UCLA men’s soccer (4-4-1, 0-2), San Diego State (3-4, 0-2)"

fields.title: redshirt sophomore
fields.content: they are considered underclassmen

fields.title: regents
fields.content: Lowercase when standing alone. Capitalize the formal title Regent when used before a full name in first reference only. e.g. Regent Yori Wada. Also capitalize the formal titles Student Regent and Student Regent-designate before a full name.

fields.title: Regents’ Professors and Lecturers Program
fields.content: uppercase Regents’ Professor and Regents’ Lecturer standalone

fields.title: relatable
fields.content: DB style accepts using this word

fields.title: resident assistant, RA
fields.content: RA on second reference; spell out on first reference

fields.title: RIMAC Arena
fields.content: RIMAC Arena ok on first ref

fields.title: rising in sports
fields.content: for fall sports, we lose the "rising designation" starting the Sunday production before c-sesh (ie the first paper of c sesh will not use rising for fall sports) All other sports use rising until the first day of classes in fall

fields.title: Riverside
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center
fields.content: Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center on first reference. For subsequent references, either the medical center or the hospital is acceptable.

fields.title: run-pass percentage
fields.content:
Run: (RUSHING YARDAGE > Rushing Attempts) / (TOTAL OFFENSE > Total Plays)

Pass: (PASSING YARDAGE > Comp-Att-Int) / (TOTAL OFFENSE > Total Plays)

fields.title: Sacramento
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: San Bernardino
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: San Jose
fields.content: The city stands alone only when it’s clear you are referring to California as there is a San Jose in Costa Rica

fields.title: Santa Barbara
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Santa Cruz
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Santa Monica
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: School of Law
fields.content: School of Law on all references.

fields.title: School of Nursing
fields.content: School of Nursing on all references.

fields.title: scientific names
fields.content: Always the full name of a gene on first reference, which doesnt have to be italicized. E.X. Insulinlike growth factor 1 instead of IGF1. Clarify whether referring to the IGF1 gene or the IGF1 protein or the gene or the protein on all subsequent references. When referring to the name of a species, capitalize and keep the rest of the formatting. For example, use Homo sapiens.

fields.title: season opener
fields.content: not hyphenated unless a modifier

fields.title: Second Takes
fields.content: Do not get column topics but do get mugs and are left aligned

fields.title: seed, seeded
fields.content: use seed whenever we use the school, "No. 4 seed UCLA," use seeded and a hyphen whenever we use the mascot "No. 4-seeded Bruins"

fields.title: Senior Day/Night
fields.content: capsed

fields.title: soccer
fields.content:
**Positions:**

* GK - Goalkeeper
* D - Defender
* MF - Midfielder
* F - Forward


**Stats:**

* GS: Games started
* G: Goals
* A: Assisted
* PTS: Points (Goals * 2 + Assists)
* SH: shots
* SH%: percentage of shots which become goals
* SOG: shots on goal
* SOG%: percentage of shots which become goals
* YC-RC: yellow cards and red cards (two yellow cards or one red card leads to ejection from a match)
* GA: goals against
* GAA: goals against average (goals against/games)
* SV: saves
* SHO: shoutouts/clean sheets


**Terms:**

* Set piece: when the ball is shot from a dead-ball, includes
+ Corner kick
+ Penalty kicks
+ Free-throws
* Clean sheet: when the team doesn’t allow a goal
* Golden goal: an overtime situation where a team needs one overtime goal to win. College soccer games are played under these rules.
* Clean sheet: when the team doesn’t allow a goal
* Golden goal: an overtime situation where a team needs one overtime goal to win. College soccer games are played under these rules.
* Silver goal: they’re a two period in overtime. If a team if winning at the end of the first, they win the game in a silver goal situation.
* Backline: the final line of defenders
* Counterattack: attacking maneuver in which several members of a defending team gain possession of the ball and suddenly counterattack into opponents half of the pitch, overwhelming opponent defense in greater numbers, usually as a result of the opposing defenders being out of position after having supported their attackers.
* Formation: the number of defenders, midfielders, and forwards respectively on the field (e.g. 4-4-2 means 4 defenders, 4 midfielders, and 2 forwards)


**Other fun stuff:**

* A win is worth three points in Pac-12 play
* Pac-12 teams in men’s soccer:
+ UCLA Bruins
+ California Golden Bears
+ Oregon State Beavers
+ Stanford Cardinal
+ Washington Huskies
+ San Diego State Aztecs
* Every Pac-12 school plays women’s soccer
+ Unlike in pro soccer, the clock is descending, not ascending.
+ CONCACAF - the North American soccer federation
+ College Cup - college soccer’s version of the NCAA tournament

fields.title: South Campus and North Campus
fields.content: Capitalize both the direction and the campus.

fields.title: special issues
fields.content: for special issues such as "Graduation Issue," "Registration Issue" or the "Rivalry Issue" capitalize the names

fields.title: spokesperson
fields.content: use to refer to people in media relations

fields.title: sports conferences
fields.content: Pac-12 on all references. Otherwise, spell out on first reference unless it's in a record. Ex: Mountain Pacific Sports Federation, Southeastern Conference.

fields.title: sports players
fields.content: Always include years and positions for UCLA student-athletes. Years are not necessary for athletes from other schools unless specifically relevant to the story.

fields.title: sports positions
fields.content: Be specific with baseball and softball players as they have positions that arent on the roster. Football positions can be specific (e.g. cornerback rather than defensive back), but explain obscure position descriptions like X receiver. Water polo, soccer and other sports have more specific positions, but the ones listed on the roster are OK. If you encounter obscure positions, check with the writer to see if they have recommendations from coaches, players, etc.

fields.title: sports team names
fields.content:
Refer to AP Stylebook for most team names, but otherwise defer to the athletic websites for the universities. In general, you can drop university.

Examples of UCLA-specific school styles:

* California then Cal
* St. Marys always
* Cal Baptist always
* Cal State Northridge then CSUN

fields.title: Statement of Principles Against Intolerance
fields.content: Spell it out in full at some point during the body of the story. In headlines and second references, you can use general language such as”UCs principles against intolerance” or “UCs intolerance policy”

fields.title: Student Activities Center, SAC
fields.content: SAC on second reference

fields.title: student advisor
fields.content: the UC’s official spelling of advisor is with an o

fields.title: Student Fees Advisory Committee, SFAC
fields.content: SFAC is acceptable on second reference

fields.title: Student Media
fields.content: Capitalize UCLA Student Media. When relevant explain that the Communications Board is the governing board of UCLA Student Media, which is the publisher of 10 publications.

fields.title: student union
fields.content: The student union encompasses USAC, GSA, services (such as the Global Viewpoint Lounge), lights and custodians but not students and restaurants. It is not interchangeable with Ackerman Union. The director of the student union can also be described as in charge of operations at Ackerman Union and Kerckhoff Hall.

fields.title: student worker
fields.content: do not hyphenate

fields.title: students from other schools
fields.content: Make sure that if you mention a student’s major who goes to another school, that it’s relevant to the story.

fields.title: summer session
fields.content: refer to classes as "A-session classes" or "C-session classes." Sessions are referred to as "A session" or "C session"

fields.title: Sunset Canyon Recreation Center
fields.content: Sunset Canyon Recreation Center on first reference. For subsequent references, either Sunset Recreation Center or Sunset Recreation is acceptable. Sunset Rec is acceptable in quotes.

fields.title: super regional
fields.content: lowercase it

fields.title: Taglines and bylines
fields.content: Place the email and Twitter handle first and then "contributing reports from" after. Follow this style: *Email Bruin at jbruin@dailybruin.com or tweet @jbruin.* *Contributing reports from Josephine Bruin, Daily Bruin senior staff.*

fields.title: TAP card
fields.content: Transit Access Pass card. Use TAP card on first reference

fields.title: telephone numbers
fields.content: Use figures. The form: 212-621-1500. For international numbers use 011 (from the United States), the country code, the city code and the telephone number: 011-44-20-7535-1515. Use hyphens, not periods. The form for toll-free numbers: 800-111-1000. If extension numbers are needed, use a comma to separate the main number from the extension: 212-621-1500, ext. 2.

fields.title: tennis court x
fields.content: for tennis court numbers do court one, court two, and court three and the like

fields.title: The Forum
fields.content: specify its in Inglewood

fields.title: The La Brea Tar Pits and Museum
The Quad
fields.content: Caps T in "The Quad"

fields.title: The Study at Hedrick
fields.content: On second reference, you can use "The Study."

fields.title: The Wiltern
fields.content: The theater capitalizes the article in front of it.

fields.title: titles
fields.content: Use ampersand if it is consistently part of the official title. For example, UCLA Housing & Hospitality Services.

fields.title: today, tonight
fields.content: Use only in direct quotations and in phrases that do not refer to a specific day: *Customs today are different from those of a century ago.* Use the day of the week in copy, not *today* or *tonight*.

fields.title: tomorrow
fields.content: Use only in direct quotations and in phrases that do not refer to a specific day: *The world of tomorrow will need additional energy resources.*Use the day of the week in other cases.

fields.title: tournament
fields.content: lowercase the t in tournament

fields.title: transfer students
fields.content: Refer to transfer students by their class year. E.x. Jacob Jacobson, a third-year political science student liked the new program. Only mention transfer status if relevant to the story. E.x. Jacob Jacobson, a third-year political science transfer student, said he found adjusting life as a transfer student tough.

fields.title: UC Board of Regents
fields.content: On first reference, use *UC Board of Regents.* On subsequent references and in headlines, *the board* or *UC Regents* are acceptable. Lowercase board and regents when used alone.

fields.title: UC campuses
fields.content: For individual schools, the format UC Irvine, UC Berkeley, etc. is acceptable on first reference. When referring to the University of California system, spell out on first reference.

fields.title: UC Student Health Insurance Plan, UC SHIP
fields.content: UC Student Health Insurance Plan on first reference. UC SHIP on all other references

fields.title: UCLA Anderson School of Management
fields.content: UCLA Anderson School of Management on first reference. On subsequent references, either School of Management or management school is acceptable.

fields.title: UCLA Athletics Director
fields.content: make sure to say Athletics in title; if not, then say athletic Director with athletic lowercased but we should be doing the former

fields.title: UCLA Dashew Center for International Students
fields.content: Dashew Center on second ref

fields.title: UCLA Free & For Sale
fields.content: we don’t need quotes but specify it is a Facebook group when mentioning it on first ref

fields.title: UCLA Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science
fields.content: on first ref, use the full name, on second ref, use School of Engineering or Samueli School of Engineering

fields.title: UCLA LGBTQ Campus Resource Center
fields.content: use LGBTQ center if full name is not used

fields.title: UCLA Memes for Sick AF Tweens
fields.content: we don’t need quotes but specify it is a Facebook group when mentioning it on first ref

fields.title: UCLA Outdoor Adventures
fields.content: Outdoor Adventures can be used on second reference

fields.title: UCLA Parking Structure x
fields.content: when referring to parking strucutres on campus, use UCLA Parking Structure followed by the number written as a numeral. Ex: "UCLA Parking Structure 2"

fields.title: UCLA Residential Life
fields.content: Do not use Office of Residential Life

fields.title: UCLA Wilshire Center
fields.content: UCLA Wilshire Center on first reference. For subsequent references, either Wilshire Center or human resources center is acceptable.

fields.title: UCPD
fields.content: Use UCPD on all references.

fields.title: undeclared physical or life sciences
fields.content: Use this term when a student says they are undeclared physical sciences, undeclared life sciences or undeclared social sciences.

fields.title: under, Uxx
fields.content: for teams that have under rankings dont use a hyphen. ex: U19

fields.title: Undergraduate Students Association Council, USAC
fields.content: Always spell out on first reference, USAC on second reference is fine; avoid USAC council, either use "USAC" or "the council"

fields.title: university apartments
fields.content: lowercase standalone. Uppercase University Apartments North and University Apartments South

fields.title: University of California Office of the President, UCOP
fields.content: UCOP is acceptable on second reference

fields.title: University of California, UC
fields.content: University of California on first ref, UC on subsequent references; remember to refer to it as an its and use a captial U when referring to the University

fields.title: URL
fields.content:
Uniform Resource Locator, an Internet address. An example:  
http://politics.ap.org/states/mi.html   
http: is the protocol, or method of transfer.  
// indicates a computer name follows.   
politics is the server.   
ap.org is the domain.   
/states is the folder.   
/mi.html indicates a file (.html is the file type). When the URL does not fit entirely on one line, break it into two or more lines without adding a hyphen or other punctuation mark.

fields.title: USA Judicial Board
fields.content: Use judicial board when standing alone. E.g. The judicial board voted in favor of the presidential candidate.

fields.title: USAC commissions
fields.content:
Capitalize the names of all commissions.

* Academic Affairs
* Campus Events
* Community Service
* Cultural Affairs
* Facilities
* Financial Supports
* Student Wellness

fields.title: USAC election
fields.content: Unless referring to multiple years of elections, use the singular form. Do not capitalize election.

fields.title: USA Elections Board
fields.content: Use election board when standing alone. E.g. The election board decides on rules and policies governing the USAC spring election. Use the full USA Election Board somewhere in the body of the story.

fields.title: USAC Election Code
fields.content: Use election code when standing alone. E.g. The election code does not permit flyering Saturdays or Sundays.

fields.title: USAC officer titles
fields.content: Avoid the redundant *USAC council member*. Use *USAC officer* or *council member* on its own. Capitalize *commissioner*, *president*, *vice president* and *general representative* when used as a formal title before a name; lowercase in all other uses: *We endorse Joe Bruin for Campus Events commissioner. USAC President Josephine Bruin called the meeting to order at 7:35 p.m.* Do not capitalize the plural form *general representatives*, even before names. Do not use acronyms for commissions or titles, including *IVP* for *internal vice president*, *CAC* for *Cultural Affairs Commission*, etc. Use USAC or councilmember on its own.

fields.title: USAC offices
fields.content: Capitalize only when referring to the formal title of the USAC office: *Office of the External Vice President*, *external vice president\'s office*. Avoid the use of numerals following *general representative*. Refer to them directly by name: *The event was put on by the offices of general representatives Joe Bruin and Josephine Bruin.*

fields.title: USAC positions
fields.content:
**Positions**

* President
* External vice president
* Internal vice president
* General representatives 1, 2 and 3
* Transfer student representative 
* International student representative
* Academic Affairs commissioner
* Campus Events commissioner
* Community Service commissioner
* Cultural Affairs commissioner
* Facilities commissioner
* Financial Supports commissioner
* Student Wellness commissioner


Capitalize commissioner, president, vice president and general representative when used as a formal title before a name; lowercase in all other uses:. E.g. We endorse Joe Bruin for Campus Events commissioner. USAC President Josephine Bruin called the meeting to order at 7:35 p.m. Do not capitalize the plural form *general representatives*, even before names.

fields.title: USAC recaps
fields.content:
Make sure the blurb about when USAC recaps take place and where at the top.

Each different section of the recap should be bolded and have a colon at the end, also make sure if there are two words included, that the second one is lowercase. 

Every point after the subheader should be in bullet points. The headline should be USAC recap (with the r lowercase), an en dash, and then the date, using AP appropriate abbreviations as necessary. USAC recaps do not get photos.

The headline should look like: *USAC recap – Sept. 14*

fields.title: USTA
fields.content: Do not spell out on first reference.

fields.title: volleyball
fields.content:
**Positions**

 * OH-Outside hitter
* MB-Middle blocker
* Opp-Opposite
* S-Setter
* L-Libero


**Stats**

 * SP-sets played
* K-kills
* E-errors
* TA-total attempts
* Pct.-hitting percentage ( [K-E]/TA)
* A-aces
* E-error
* SA-service ace
* SE-service error
* BS-block solo
* BA-block assist
* BE-blocking error
* DIG-digs
* BHE-ball-handling error
* RA-reception attempts
* RE-reception error
* Pts.-K + SA+BS+ (½)BA
* K/S-kills per set (Total Kills/Total Sets Played)
* AST/S-assists per set (Total Assists/Total Sets Played)
* A/S-aces per set (Total Aces/Total Sets Played)
* D/S-digs per set (Total Digs/Total Sets Played)
* B/S
* Individual (Total BS + Total BA/Total Sets Played)
* Team (Total BS + (½)Total BA/Total Sets Played)


**Others notes:**

* UCLA plays in the MPSF in men’s volleyball and in the Pac-12 in women’s volleyball
* MPSF teams in men’s volleyball are the:
+ UCLA Bruins
+ BYU Cougars
+ Pepperdine Waves
+ Concordia Eagles
+ Grand Canyon Antelopes
+ Stanford Cardinal
+ USC Trojans
* Volleyball matches are best of five, with teams aiming to get 25 points in the first four sets and 15 points in the fifth set
* Men’s volleyball uses the AVCA Rankings
* Women’s volleyball uses the AVCA Rankings
* Both men’s and women’s volleyball finish in their respective NCAA tournaments. Six teams qualify for the men’s volleyball tournament while 32 teams qualify for the women’s volleyball tournament.

fields.title: water polo
fields.content:
**Positions**

* GK - goalkeeper
* D - defender
* UTL - utility
* ATK - attacker
* C - center


**Other stuff:**

* 6-on-5/power play: When one team has more players than the other in the pool because someone from the other team was penalized.
* Big Four - the four schools traditionally best at college water polo: USC, UCLA, Stanford, and California
* MPSF teams in men’s water polo:
+ Stanford Cardinal
+ USC Trojans
+ UCLA Bruins
+ Penn State Behrend
+ Austin College
* MPSF teams in women’s water polo
USC

fields.title: weeks
fields.content: do not capitalize and do not use numerals unless it’s week 10

fields.title: West Hollywood
fields.content: The city in California stands alone in Daily Bruin stories.

fields.title: Westwood Neighborhood Council
fields.content: use WWNC on second reference

fields.title: Westwood Regency theaters
fields.content: The Regency Village Theatre refers to the movie theater with the Fox tower, and the Regency Bruin Theater refers to the theater with "Bruin" on its front. When referring to them collectively, you can say "Regency theaters in Westwood."

fields.title: Westwood Village Improvement Association
fields.content: A business improvement district is a precisely defined geographical area where businesses vote to invest collectively in local improvements. The Westwood Village Improvement Association operates a BID called the Westwood Business Improvement District, but colloquially the association is commonly also referred to as the BID. Avoid this usage; only refer to the BID when speaking about the geographical area.On first reference, explain the relationship between the association and the BID: *The Westwood Village Improvement Association, which operates the Westwood Business Improvement District, hired a new assistant director*.On subsequent references, *association* is preferred. In cases in which a source refers to the association as the BID, change to *association* and enclose within parentheses: *"The (association) is spending too much money on administrative overhead," said Jerry Brown, president of the Westwood Neighborhood Council.*Do not use *BID* in headlines. Instead, use *Westwood leaders* or *Westwood officials*.

fields.title: wire-to-wire
fields.content: maintaining a lead for the entire game

fields.title: words in other languages
fields.content: Explain what they mean not in quotes. In special circumstances, like a PRIME story in which someone traveled, italics can be acceptable with writer approval or approval from hte source. Whatever you decide, keep it consistent throughout the story.

fields.title: wrap boxes in print
fields.content:
The winning team and their score is bolded in demi bold. Home teams are on the bottom, while away teams are at the top. if it’s at a neutral location check which team is considered which.For wrap boxes of NCAA tournament or conference tournament do No. \_\_ seed, not just No. \_\_\_

Ex:

WOMEN’S SOCCER

**No. 2 seed UCLA 4**

No. 1 seed Florida State 0

fields.title: year ranges
fields.content: use the full year when doing year ranges, so 2019-2020 NOT 2019-20

fields.title: Zero Waste initiative
fields.content: Do not capitalize the i in initiative as it is not what the website does
